Description: This lamp is made of a light coloured clay. There is an incised ring around the pouring hole and a side lug, as well as blackening around the wick hole. There is also an amount of material remaining in the oil reservoir.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Nottingham Castle Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Late 4th or 3rd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Blondé 1998, 321-22, no. 16). A late (un-slipped) Broneer type VIII lamp with parallels from Corinth (Broneer 1930, 47, no.137) and Howland type 25D from Athens in an Attic clay (Howland 1958, 79, dated 350BC-275BC). Blondé, F. 1998. Lampes tournée Hellénistiques du Musée d’Alexandrie, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 307-35. Broneer, O. 1930. Corinth IV.II, Terracotta lamps, Princeton. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.43) (Phase 3)
